name: Data-management-and-visualization3
body:
## Third assignment

My dataset is the Gapminder dataset. 
My codebook:
* femaleemployrate: (2007) female employees age 15+ (% of the population). Percentage of female population, age above 15, that has been employed during the given year.
* employrate: (2007) total employees age 15+ (% of the population). Percentage of total population, age above 15, that has been employed during the given year.
* lifeexpectancy 2011 life expectancy at birth (years). The average number of years a newborn child would live if current mortality patterns were to stay the same.
* urbanrate (2008) urban population (% of total). Urban population refers to people living in urban areas as defined by national statistical offices (calculated using World Bank population estimates and urban ratios from the United Nations World Urbanization Prospects).

This assignment is about data management. My dataset contains only continuous variables, there is no categorical variable, which makes this job a little harder. There is no missing data and nan data in these set, so I could not use any methodology to solve such a problem. So I tried to subsetting my data and analyse it.

### Code
`import pandas
import numpy

pandas.options.display.float_format = '{:,.2f}'.format
data = pandas.read_csv('gapminder.csv', low_memory = False)
data_columns = map(str.lower, data.columns)

#setting variables you will be working with to numeric

data['femaleemployrate'] = data['femaleemployrate'].convert_objects(convert_numeric=True)
data['employrate'] = data['employrate'].convert_objects(convert_numeric=True)
data['lifeexpectancy'] = data['lifeexpectancy'].convert_objects(convert_numeric=True)
data['urbanrate'] = data['urbanrate'].convert_objects(convert_numeric=True)

#frequency counts
data1 = data.copy()
data1['lifeexpectancy_range'] = pandas.cut(data1.lifeexpectancy, range(0,110, 10))
le = data1['lifeexpectancy_range'].value_counts(sort = False, normalize = True)

data1['femaleemployrate_range'] = pandas.cut(data1.femaleemployrate, range(0,110, 10))
fe = data1['femaleemployrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False, normalize= True)

data1['employrate_range']= pandas.cut(data1.employrate, range(0,110, 10))
em = data1['employrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

data1['urbanrate_range']= pandas.cut(data1.urbanrate, range(0,110, 10))
ur = data1['urbanrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

result =result3 = pandas.concat([le, fe, em, ur], axis=1, join='inner') 

sub2 = data[data['lifeexpectancy']>= 70]
sub3 = sub2.copy()
sub3 = sub3[['femaleemployrate','employrate', 'urbanrate', 'lifeexpectancy']]

sub3['lifeexpectancy_range'] = pandas.cut(sub3.lifeexpectancy, range(0,110, 10))
le3 = sub3['lifeexpectancy_range'].value_counts(sort = False, normalize = True)

sub3['femaleemployrate_range'] = pandas.cut(sub3.femaleemployrate, range(0,110, 10))
fe3 = sub3['femaleemployrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False, normalize= True)

sub3['employrate_range']= pandas.cut(sub3.employrate, range(0,110, 10))
em3 = sub3['employrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

sub3['urbanrate_range']= pandas.cut(sub3.urbanrate, range(0,110, 10))
ur3 = sub3['urbanrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

result3 = pandas.concat([le3, fe3, em3, ur3], axis=1, join='inner')



sub4 = data[data['urbanrate']>= 60]

sub4['lifeexpectancy_range'] = pandas.cut(sub4.lifeexpectancy, range(0,110, 10))
le4 = sub4['lifeexpectancy_range'].value_counts(sort = False, normalize = True)

sub4['femaleemployrate_range'] = pandas.cut(sub4.femaleemployrate, range(0,110, 10))
fe4 = sub4['femaleemployrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False, normalize= True)

sub4['employrate_range']= pandas.cut(sub4.employrate, range(0,110, 10))
em4 = sub4['employrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

sub4['urbanrate_range']= pandas.cut(sub4.urbanrate, range(0,110, 10))
ur4 = sub4['urbanrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

result4 = pandas.concat([le4, fe4, em4, ur4], axis=1, join='inner')



sub5 = data[data['femaleemployrate']>= 50]

sub5['lifeexpectancy_range'] = pandas.cut(sub5.lifeexpectancy, range(0,110, 10))
le5 = sub5['lifeexpectancy_range'].value_counts(sort = False, normalize = True)

sub5['femaleemployrate_range'] = pandas.cut(sub5.femaleemployrate, range(0,110, 10))
fe5 = sub5['femaleemployrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False, normalize= True)

sub5['employrate_range']= pandas.cut(sub5.employrate, range(0,110, 10))
em5 = sub5['employrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

sub5['urbanrate_range']= pandas.cut(sub5.urbanrate, range(0,110, 10))
ur5 = sub5['urbanrate_range'].value_counts(sort= False,normalize = True)

result5 = pandas.concat([le5, fe5, em5, ur5], axis=1, join='inner')

print ""
print '0: life expectancy, 1: female employrate, 2: employrate, 3: urbanrate'
print ""
print "Original frequency tables"
print result
print ""
print "Life expectancy more than 70 years"
print result3
print ""
print "Urbanrate more than 60%"
print result4 
print ""
print "Female employrate more than 50%"
print result5`

###Results:
[Frequency tables](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B9RU8CIct6N8ZjUxRHd2SzNRa28)

###Evaluation:
* Life expectancy more than 70 years
I have chosen 70 years because range between 70-80 years is the most frequent. Between female employ rate and life expectancy have no direct connection, there is only a slight difference between the original and subsetted results. There is more effect on the employrate, there is no change in the maximum at 50-60%, but the ratio is changed from 0.31 to 0.40, and the 80-90% range was disappeared, so the connection is not linear between the employrate and life expectancy, but this will need more detailed analysis later. But in more urbanised countries usually, people live longer, from 60% urban rate this effect is more obvious.
* Urban rate more than 60%
The connection of life expectancy and the urban rate is seen here: 70-80: 56%. For employ rates, the effect is complex, narrowed the range. 
* Female employ rate more than 50%
Female employ rate change life expectancy, the maximum lowered to 60-70 years range, but more people live longer than 80 years. In this case, the overall employrate is between 60-80%. Female employ rate slightly affects the urban rate, which is around 10% in almost all ranges.

## Fourth assignment

Visualization of the dataset
###Code (just for this assigment, the others can be seen above)

`print "Descriptive statistrics"
desc1 = data['lifeexpectancy'].describe()
print desc1

desc2 = data['femaleemployrate'].describe()
print desc2

desc3 = data['employrate'].describe()
print desc3

desc4 = data['urbanrate'].describe()
print desc4

plot1 = seaborn.distplot(data["lifeexpectancy"].dropna(), kde=False);
plt.xlabel('Life expectancy')
plt.title('Expected life expectancy in Gapminder dataset')
plt.savefig('lifeexp.png')
plt.close()

plot2 = seaborn.distplot(data["femaleemployrate"].dropna(), kde=False);
plt.xlabel('Woman employrate')
plt.title('Woman employrate in Gapminder dataset')
plt.savefig('womanemp.png')
plt.close()

plot3 = seaborn.distplot(data["employrate"].dropna(), kde=False);
plt.xlabel('Employ rate')
plt.title('Employ rate in Gapminder dataset')
plt.savefig('emp.png')
plt.close()

plot4 = seaborn.distplot(data["urbanrate"].dropna(), kde=False);
plt.xlabel('Urban rate')
plt.title('Urban rate in Gapminder dataset')
plt.savefig('urban.png')
plt.close()

scat1 = seaborn.regplot(x="lifeexpectancy", y="femaleemployrate", data=data)
plt.xlabel('Life expectancy')
plt.ylabel('Female employ rate')
plt.title('Scatterplot for the Association Between Life Expectancy and Female Employrate')
plt.savefig('testplot.png')
plt.close()

scat2 = seaborn.regplot(x="lifeexpectancy", y="employrate", data=data)
plt.xlabel('Life expectancy')
plt.ylabel('Employ rate')
plt.title('Scatterplot for the Association Between Life Expectancy and Employrate')
plt.savefig('testplot2.png')
plt.close()

scat3 = seaborn.regplot(x="lifeexpectancy", y="urbanrate", data=data)
plt.xlabel('Life expectancy')
plt.ylabel('Urban rate')
plt.title('Scatterplot for the Association Between Life Expectancy and Urban rate')
plt.savefig('testplot3.png')
plt.close()
`

### Figures and evaluation
Univariate graphs

[Life expectancy](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8TThySFZHVEVaS2s/view?usp=sharing)

Spread: range from 47.8 to 83.4 years (moderately wide), right-skewed shape, mean 69.8 (std = 9.8) years.

[Female employrate](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8VXpiRmFlbmlsLW8/view?usp=sharing)

Spread: range from 11.3 to 83.3% (really wide), centered shape, mean 47.6 (std = 14.6) %.

[Employ rate](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8OWxrZWc3MmZhTjQ/view?usp=sharing)

Spread: range from 32.0 to 83.2% (wide), centered shape, mean 58.6 (std = 10.5) %.

[Urban rate](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8allEd2M2RFNpWVE/view?usp=sharing)

Spread: range from 10.4 to 100.0%, slightly right-skewed, mean 56.8 (std = 23.8) %.

Bivariate graphs

[Life expectancy - Female Employrate](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8M2FES1BjR3lPdEE/view?usp=sharing)

There is a slight negative correlation between the life expectancy and female employrate, causes could be really interesting to find.

[Life expectancy - Employrate](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8bUpSLWNHRlFKYlk/view?usp=sharing)

There is a slight negative correlation between the life expectancy and employrate (approximately the same grade as in case of female employrate), causes could be really interesting to find.

[Life expectancy - Urban rate](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9RU8CIct6N8Wm5PbVhhZUxsQVk/view?usp=sharing)

There is a positive correlation between the life expectancy and urban rate, causes could be better availabilty to work, healthcare, etc.
